reviewText: These plays were okay, I'm glad I rented them before buying them.  The props and things were very nice, the actors didn't gel well with each other or connect with their characters and the singing was mediocre ( definitely no Tyler Perry quality on that note) but the messages were good just seemed a little unrealistic and too drawn out.  I thought Alexander O'Neal sang in one of them but he didn't.
summary: Rent if you want to see, not a collectors item

reviewText: I must admit, I initially did not think this would be a quality production, but it was. They did a much better job than I expected. The music was very inspirational and the story of redemption was very powerful. It made you remember that Jesus came for the lost - who needed him - not just for the folks who have it all together and never messed up. The viewer was challenged to remember the real purpose of Christ's entry into humanity. This would be great for folks who have been long-time church goers as a reminder of what it really means to be a Christian.

reviewText: It was okay, the beginning was very slow and I lost interest a few times. About an hour into it, it picked up and held my attention. I guess I missed the laugh out loud moments that others mentioned in there reviews and the singing was average. Perhaps TP has spoiled me but I didn't care for the choir director's voice. There were No BIG stand out messages or memoriable parts. Nephew Tommy was good but he just wasn't believable as a thug/drug dealer mostly because I'm use to his comic side on the Steve Harvey Morning Show and his side kick D is also a comedian so their roles to be were like Blah. I say rent it or borrow it, or if you can get a $4.50 deal from one of the market sellers like I did then its worth the purchase if you like collection black stage plays.

reviewText: I recently discovered David Talbert's work and while he is no Tyler Perry, I think that's the point, all of us have different gifts.  This was a well written play about standing up to the evil that has infiltrated our communities.  The young Pastor represents the kind of men we need to step up and stand up.  It was uplifting to see the transformation of Clifton Powell's character and how even those around him could be impacted by realzing that its not just a game but its real life and death.  All in all this was a good play and well worth the time.
summary: Good Play with a Powerful Message
Title: N/A

reviewText: DO we always have to have the loveliest and most innocent young lady brutally beaten on the way home?Do we always need to see the innocent and the good left out in the cold, while the bad get badder and richer?Let's just have a joyful, hollywood ending, even with some loose threads dangling . . .I love this movie and if we had MORE MOVIES like this one, we would have no more killings, but people in church rejoicnig, no matter how small the church, no matter how hard the life and deep the humiliationsthis reminds me precisely like so many tiny storefront chapels in the inner city, with all of its cultural markers, that I am very grateful to feel a part of this congregation of real saints once more.the music truly brings you to tears and the pastor to salvationlet us watch this film in peace and joy and arise.here at long last is a film worth watchinglisten to the audio commentary track as well to answer several of your questionsIs there a soundtrack release? I would love to have these profoundly moving hymns and background music separately as well.Just an additional note: Sister Julie Dickens is a very talented and attractive actress, like Mr. CLifton Powell, and she truly conveys a church sister sanctified testifying with powerful song. I wish I could find something else she has done as she is so wonderful here, a thin little wisp of a holy woman with a voice that fills an auditorium with power and purity and IN TUNE, so rare today, like all these here, IN TUNE, like you do not hear anymore but in church. I wish Mr. Talbert had stayed with what he knows from his family: storefront church and done more of these, the SPirit conquers and Love is supreme, with JOY and blessings. This would be wonderful but it feels like his unchurched wife took over and he wound up doing simple light romantic comedies. I wish we had more of these and more of Julie Dickens. Just saying. Also MR. Powell does a WONDERFUL and powerful Dr. King and I wish seriously he had done it on film.
summary: Why can't Hollywood have Hollywood Endings like this one!

reviewText: I enjoyed this play; I showed this play to some of my friends and they all said David Talbert is no Tyler Perry.  No he is not, he is writing stage plays with a message!  I liked the fact that he showed the Pastor giving up his life for the Lord.  Also, the Deacon felt that he should be next in line for pastorial duties, but the members felt he was not qualified.  They began interviewing ministers and just when they were about to give up hope in walks this young minister packing a powerful punch.  The play toggles back and forth between good and evil.  Clifton Powell was great in this play as one of the forces of evil.  When the walls began to fall down in his life, he gives up the right for the wrong.  The singing in this play was fantastic and the acting was great.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Unlike any of Tyler Perry's features, this play has themes that are much darker and edgier.  I don't recommend showing this to young children.  There are a couple scenes in which church members are either shot or threatened with weapons by gangsters.  No blood, of course, but the actions are very apparent.The script has a bit of a haphazard to slow start before getting to the crux of the story, and the rag tag members of the True Vine church are not characters one would seem to sympathize with except for the new pastor who seems to have the only real zeal of faith to make things happen.Perhaps it was as director/writer David Talbert had envisioned.  He is able to depict the very raw and seedy side of the Detroit Streets.  The actor who plays Demetrius plays his gangster role so well and so powerfully, you cannot help but hating his antagonizing character.  He is a thug, and he is mean.But the play does have a redemptive quality.  Crime boss Satin Jones, played by Clifton Powell, is able to repent of his ways.  His monologue at the end of the play is done with the right pace, intensity and interpretation.  At one point he breaks character as chokes tearfully in emotion and has a hard time delivering his next line, but it just made the scene that much better.Not the uplifting in rejoice ending you would be expecting, but there is a silver lining to this cloud.  Just be sure you check the weather carefully before venturing outdoors...with the young ones.
summary: Screen this before showing Young Children

I personally missed out on the theme of it because of all of the over dramatic actors in it. I like David Talbert's work however this one needs to be made over. (Even turning down the volume does not help). Seriously!

reviewText: I just bought the play today and sat down to watch it tonight, and I liked to shed a few tears at the end; It goes like this: you have this drug dealer, Satin Jones(Clifton Powell),whose bar sits right next door to a church; his underling becomes too ambitious and threatens to take over the church; the pastor is already gunned down in a confrontation with them; and Satin is ready to close in on the property of the church next door to "expand" his territory; when he asks his people to wait on this, his associate,in direct opposition to what Satin said, goes to the church, terrorizes the members and beats up the new preacher; despite of all of this, the church presses on and even a love thing goes on between the preacher and one of the members; The ending of the play is the absolute best and will make you want to cry; What I learned most out of this play is that no matter how things may look or seem, things can go up after being down. Recommended viewing. One more thing, I started watching David Talbert before getting in on Tyler; I won't compare but I will say that I thank God for the both of them and that there is room for them both;
Title: N/A
